page.title: 11SPAINS HALL, FINCHINGFIELD.
page.content: This brief history of the estate at Spains Hall begins with the Domesday Survey of 1O86.After the Norman Conquest it belonged to Hervy de Ispania.The original Norman house was succeeded by a moated timber-framed house parts of which are still extant.The present house was largely built in 1585 by William Kempe.In 176O the estate was purchased from his descendant Lady Swinnerton Dyer by Samuel Ruggles a clothier from Bocking, Essex.A later Ruggles,Thomas, married Anne Brise. Thus, only three families, de Ispania,Kempe and Ruggles Brise have lived in Spains Hall since the eleventh century an interesting example of continuity in English country life. Today the house remains the most important in the area.That is why it is in this Domesday survey of 1985.
